heisig_chinese_memo: The li is a Chinese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.
heisig_constituent: ri, computer, rice field, brains, soil, dirt, ground
heisig_story: That's right - a ri. Don't bother looking it up in your English dictionary; it's a Japanese word for measuring distances. One ri is about 4 kilometers or 2.5 miles. The kanji depicts how the measure came to be used. Atop we see the rice field, and below the element for land. Those four sections you see in the rice field (and which we made mention of when first we introduced the character in frame 14) are actually measurements of land, much the same as farm-sections in the United States have given us the notion of a "country mile." The land division based on the size of a rice field is called a ri.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The village you always think of first is your home village.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Why would you ever talk about the village where someone else was born? Answer: you wouldn't. Everything is always about you.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You go back to your home village in a saddle (ã•ã¨). You can't take a car or a train there, it's really in the middle of nowhere. So you have to ride a horse, so break out that old saddle and go visit your parents.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Close your eyes and imagine being on a saddle, heading back to your home village right now. Feel your butt and legs chafing. Eh... that's not such a great memory, now that you think about it.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Back in the old days, instead of having a micro-computer sewn inside the suit of the master spy, a whole computer was carried inside the back of his cloak, although it was clearly obvious that he was a spy. "What's that um.. enormous computer doing inside the back of your cloak?".
origin_of_ch_char_book: Ancient eastern people worshiped the earth. So, they tried to preserve the natural land rather than cultivate and develop it. They thought of the earth as their mother because all the creatures come from the earth. (é‡Œ, li, place, inside) The upper one (ç”°, tian=tâ€™ien, field) means field divided into four places, and lower one (åœŸ, tu, soil) means the earth on which some corps are rising, and it also means an altar people gathering. The whole character means the village where people gather in the field, performing rites. In the past, people considered that the earth of their hometown would protect them, and they worshiped the god of their own territory by building an altar. This god of hometown would judge the people of the village whether to go to Heaven or to go to hell. (ç†, li, manage, reason) The left side of the symbol (ç‰, yu=yÃ¼, jade) is a jade bead, and the right side is a village where people live together. The ancient people believed that the jade are so pure than any other existences of the earth, and they believed that the jade is a soul of the land which can defeat the evil spirits. Because jade (ç‰) can judge people of the village with the spirit of the earth (åœŸ), is used as a meaning of control, manage, reason etc.
humanum_full_description_en:
From the " field " to the " earth ", the original meaning is the place where the ancient villagers lived together. The word " li " was first seen in the inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty, from the " field " to the " earth ", it means that the earth can live in the earth. In the Western Zhou Dynasty, the inscriptions " tian " and " earth " were drawn through, and after the late Zhou Dynasty, it was customary to extend the dots on the vertical pen beside the earth into short horizontal lines, which was the origin of the word " li " in the seal script. "Shu Wen": "Li, live in. From the field, from the soil. All the genus from the inside." It is said that after the ancestors' agriculture developed and the fields were cultivated, they could not settle down, so from " " Tian " means "home" from " earth " (see Dai Jiaxiang). Simplified from this " clothing ", " where " sound " in " word incorporated " in " see " inside ."

Bronze inscriptions are used as the original meaning, such as Ling Fang Yi: "Li Jun", which means the length of the li; also express the unit of length, such as Zhongshan Wangding: "fang hundreds of miles"; also used as " li ", and " table " relatively. For example, Bo Pingding: "Li (li)you" means that the inside of the clothes is black.

The bamboo slips of the Warring States period use its original meaning, such as "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Letter 15 of "Closed Diagnosis Style": "In a certain county in a certain mile"; also used as a unit of length, such as "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Japanese Book A Type "Simplified 131: "You must die two hundred miles away"; it is also commonly used as " Li ", meaning governance, such as "Guodian Jian. "Yu Cong Yi" Jan 54: "The sage (sage) can be in the (li)".

" Li " in Han silk script is also commonly used as " li " to express truth, such as "Mawangdui. The 65th line of "Tian Xia Zhi Dao Tan": "Mu Mu Zhi Li (Li)", which means the principle of male and female.
humanum_short_description_en: From the " field " to the " earth ", the original meaning is a place where ancient villagers lived together.

origin_of_ch_char_book: Ancient eastern people worshiped the earth. So, they tried to preserve the natural land rather than cultivate and develop it. They thought of the earth as their mother because all the creatures come from the earth. (é‡Œ, li, place, inside) The upper one (ç”°, tian=tâ€™ien, field) means field divided into four places, and lower one (åœŸ, tu, soil) means the earth on which some corps are rising, and it also means an altar people gathering. The whole character means the village where people gather in the field, performing rites. In the past, people considered that the earth of their hometown would protect them, and they worshiped the god of their own territory by building an altar. This god of hometown would judge the people of the village whether to go to Heaven or to go to hell. (ç†, li, manage, reason) The left side of the symbol (ç‰, yu=yÃ¼, jade) is a jade bead, and the right side is a village where people live together. The ancient people believed that the jade are so pure than any other existences of the earth, and they believed that the jade is a soul of the land which can defeat the evil spirits. Because jade (ç‰) can judge people of the village with the spirit of the earth (åœŸ), is used as a meaning of control, manage, reason etc.

Heisig constituents: ri, computer, rice field, brains, soil, dirt, ground
Heisig: That's right - a ri. Don't bother looking it up in your English dictionary; it's a Japanese word for measuring distances. One ri is about 4 kilometers or 2.5 miles. The kanji depicts how the measure came to be used. Atop we see the rice field, and below the element for land. Those four sections you see in the rice field (and which we made mention of when first we introduced the character in frame 14) are actually measurements of land, much the same as farm-sections in the United States have given us the notion of a "country mile." The land division based on the size of a rice field is called a ri.
* To get a more concrete primitive meaning for this kanji, we shall refer to it as a computer, a meaning deriving from the kanji for logic, which we will meet in Lesson 12.
Chinese: The li is a Chinese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.
koohii1: The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.

From the " field" to the " earth", the original meaning is the place where the ancient villagers lived together. The word " li" was first seen in the inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty, from the " field" to the " earth", it means that the earth can live in the earth. In the Western Zhou Dynasty, the inscriptions " tian" and " earth" were drawn through, and after the late Zhou Dynasty, it was customary to extend the dots on the vertical pen beside the earth into short horizontal lines, which was the origin of the word " li" in the seal script. "Shu Wen": "Li, live in. From the field, from the soil. All the genus from the inside." It is said that after the ancestors' agriculture developed and the fields were cultivated, they could not settle down, so from " " Tian" means "home" from " earth" (see Dai Jiaxiang). Simplified from this " clothing", " where" sound " in" word incorporated " in" see " inside." Bronze inscriptions are used as the original meaning, such as Ling Fang Yi: "Li Jun", which means the length of the li; also express the unit of length, such as Zhongshan Wangding: "fang hundreds of miles"; also used as " li", and " table" relatively. For example, Bo Pingding: "Li (li)you" means that the inside of the clothes is black. The bamboo slips of the Warring States period use its original meaning, such as "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Letter 15 of "Closed Diagnosis Style": "In a certain county in a certain mile"; also used as a unit of length, such as "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Japanese Book A Type "Simplified 131: "You must die two hundred miles away"; it is also commonly used as " Li", meaning governance, such as "Guodian Jian. "Yu Cong Yi" Jan 54: "The sage (sage) can be in the (li)". " Li" in Han silk script is also commonly used as " li" to express truth, such as "Mawangdui. The 65th line of "Tian Xia Zhi Dao Tan": "Mu Mu Zhi Li (Li)", which means the principle of male and female.

Radicals: é‡Œ  (village)
Meaning Mnemonic
The village you always think of first is your home village.
Why would you ever talk about the village where someone else was born? Answer: you wouldn't. Everything is always about you.
Reading Mnemonic
You go back to your home village in a saddle (ã•ã¨). You can't take a car or a train there, it's really in the middle of nowhere. So you have to ride a horse, so break out that old saddle and go visit your parents.
Close your eyes and imagine being on a saddle, heading back to your home village right now. Feel your butt and legs chafing. Eh... that's not such a great memory, now that you think about it.
